title: Australian scientists make breakthrough in fight against superbugs
text:
"It won't stop superbugs from being out there, but it will allow us to treat superbugs," she said. 
"Many of these superbugs are superbugs because of this masking function. 
"What this research will do is allow us to de-mask the bacteria." 
Professor Vrielink said genes containing the colistan-resistant protein could move between bacteria, resulting in previously treatable bacterial infections becoming untreatable. 
"If this resistance has moved into the human population we have an alarming situation on our hands," she said. 
"I would consider antibacterial resistance to be one of our largest public health threats." Breakthrough motivation for further research 
The University of Western Australia's School of Molecular Sciences used a technique called X-ray crystallography to map the shape of EptA. 
Professor Vrielink said the discovery was very exciting. 
"It gives you an enormous sense of satisfaction that you're seeing something that no-one has ever seen before," she said. 
"You get a much better appreciation for how that molecule works and that drives your further research to try and find a therapeutic treatment." 
The development of a drug to prevent the masking of bacteria is still a number of years away, but Professor Vrielink said this breakthrough opened the door to combating the threat of antibiotic resistance. What are antibiotics? Antibiotics are a broad class of drugs that work by inhibiting the function of bacterial cells. They do this by killing the bacteria or stopping them from reproducing â€“ but have no effect on viruses. They are used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, pneumonia or skin infections
